issues.description: The problem statement explicitly asks for a modifiable List<Meal> attribute called `orders` (and the UML also shows `orders (List)`), but the solution (and the provided helpers in the template) model the order storage as a Meal[] array (`private Meal[] orders;` and getOrders() returns Meal[]). This is a structural mismatch: students reading the statement will implement a List<Meal> as instructed, while the template/solution (and ArrayHelpers) expect array usage. This difference affects field type, getter signature, and most code that manipulates the orders collection and can cause confusion or test mismatches.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the collection type consistent across all artifacts. Either: (A) Update the problem statement and UML to specify that `orders` is a Meal[] (array) and mention usage of the provided ArrayHelpers, or (B) change the template/solution to use a modifiable List<Meal> everywhere (replace array usage and ArrayHelpers-based manipulations with List operations). Prefer option A if the ArrayHelpers and other classes are intended to be used as-is.

issues.description: The problem text instructs that the SealSaloon attributes "should be initialized to default values ... in the constructor of SealSaloon" (implying instance initialization), but later explicitly requires the `stock` attribute to be static and that related methods be static. This can confuse students about whether `stock` should be an instance (initialized in the constructor) or a static class member (initialized at declaration or in a static initializer). The solution declares `private static final Stock stock = new Stock();`, which is consistent with the later note but inconsistent with the earlier guidance to initialize in the constructor.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify the wording in the problem statement: explicitly state that `stock` is a static (class-level) field and therefore should be initialized at declaration or in a static initializer, while `orders` (the per-instance collection) should be initialized in the constructor. This removes the apparent contradiction between "initialize in the constructor" and the later requirement that `stock` be static.
